title: 1. Casual Greeting
en: In casual meetings, it is common to smile, make eye contact, and say a simple 'Hi' or 'Hello'.

title: 2. Formal Greeting
en: In formal settings, shake hands firmly and address people by their title and surname.

title: 3. Greeting Gesture
en: Depending on culture, greetings may include a handshake, a nod, or a light cheek kiss. Always follow the other personâ€™s lead.

title: 4. Common Greetings
en: Common greetings in meetings include 'How are you?', 'Nice to meet you', or 'Good morning'.

title: 5. Queue Etiquette
en: When entering a meeting room or event, wait for your turn and avoid pushing in front of others.

title: 6. Dining Politeness
en: If food is served during a meeting, wait until everyone is served before you start eating.

title: 7. Respecting Diversity
en: Respect different cultural, religious, and dietary preferences during meetings and events.

title: 8. Seating Etiquette
en: In formal meetings, wait to be shown your seat. In casual settings, ask politely before choosing a seat.

title: 9. Mobile Phone Manners
en: Keep your phone on silent mode during meetings and avoid answering non-urgent calls.

title: 10. Turn Taking in Meetings
en: Speak one at a time and wait for your turn to contribute, without interrupting others.

title: 11. Disagreeing Politely
en: When disagreeing, use polite phrases like 'I see it differently' instead of blunt refusals.

title: 12. Using Titles
en: Address colleagues formally with titles and surnames until invited to use first names.

title: 13. Body Language
en: Maintain open body language, such as sitting upright and nodding, to show engagement.

title: 14. Ending a Meeting
en: Meetings usually end with a summary of key points and clear action steps.

title: 15. Follow-up After Meeting
en: Send follow-up emails or notes after the meeting to confirm agreements and responsibilities.
